newsitem.title: USA: FTC will not duplicate Justice efforts on Microsoft.
newsitem.headline: FTC will not duplicate Justice efforts on Microsoft.

text.p: As expected, the Federal Trade Commission told three senators Tuesday it cannot conduct an investigation of Microsoft Corp because to do so would duplicate efforts of the Justice Department.
Three senators, unhappy the Justice Department has not taken more action against Microsoft, asked the FTC to intervene.

But in letters to Republican Senators Ted Stevens of Alaska, Conrad Burns of Montana, and Craig Thomas of Wyoming, FTC Chairman Robert Pitofsky said the commission "has concluded that to exercise its authority ... could involve a substantial duplication of effort."
Pitofsky said that so far as he knew the FTC had never invoked its authority to investigate "in the context of an active investigation of the same subject by the Department of Justice."
Pitofsky declined to say specifically that the Justice Department was in fact conducting such an investigation, although the letter certainly left the door open to that possibility.
But he said that the FTC had decided "that it cannot responsibly commence the investigation that you have requested."
One of the Senate aides who helped draft the letter said the response was as expected.
"It's not particularly a surprise," said the aide.
